captions.text:
You can cue your dog to go into his crate
by teaching him a cue word, such as "Go to

bed." So I'm going to show you a couple of
ways to do that. You can actually teach your

puppy to go into his crate on cue. And this
is what I'm gonna do now. I'm gonna place

a treat in the crate. As puppy goes in, I'm
going to give the cue: "Go to bed." Go to

bed. Good boy. Good boy. You can actually
see he's working out so quickly that this

is where the good stuff happens, so he just
stayed in his crate for a couple of seconds

to see if he'd get anything else. Go to bed.
Good boy. Now, I use a lure with my hand in

the crate with a treat coming through with
my hand here, and I'm gonna tell him to go

to bed. Let's see if he can work it out. As
he goes into the crate, I'm gonna give him

the cue word, so he begins to associate the
action of going in the crate with the word.

Let's watch him work out how's he's going
to get that piece of food: He's got to go

into his crate to go get it. As he's gonna
go into his crate, I'm gonna tell him to go

to bed: Go to bed. Good boy. Good boy. Nice.
Go to bed. Good boy. After repeating this

a couple of times, you're just going to use
your hand as the lure without a treat in there.

Go to bed. Good boy. Now he's just gonna get
praise: Good boy. Now, I'm going to actually

add the food back in. He never knows when
he's gonna get the food. And when you do this

kind of reenforcement --sometimes the dog
gets food when the dog complies, sometimes

doesn't-- it actually makes the dog work even
harder. Because at the end of the day, you

don't want to give him food every single time
he goes into his crate. So this is starting

to build-up that cue word, that whenever he
hears it, he's gonna go into his crate whether

there's gonna be food or not. Go to bed. Good
boy. Good boy. Good boy. Go to bed. Good boy.

Good boy. Now, I'm gonna try it without the
hand being there as the lure: Go to bed. This

is hard, because he's got to make the association
with the word and the actual action of going

in there. Has he made it? Let's see. Go to
bed. Go 
to bed. Good boy. Good boy. Shut the crate

door. Good boy. Yes, very good boy. Open the
crate door. Good boy. Very good. You can also

catch your behavior. So, for example, even
if you haven't cued your dog to go to bed,

if you catch your dog actually in the act
of walking into his crate, just say that cue

word, so that he really begins to associate
that group of words-- the action of going

into his crate. The thing that I love about
puppies is they learn so fast. And the wonderful

thing, also, is I'm not forcing him to do
anything. He's making choices. If he makes

the right choices, he gets great rewards.
And remember, every dog is motivated by different

rewards: Some dogs are motivated by food.
Some dogs are motivated by toys. Some play,

some praise, some petting-- it doesn't matter,
just find your dog or your puppies biggest

motivator, and use it. That's how you teach
your dog to go to bed, positively. I'm Victoria
Stilwell for eHow Pets.

title: Teach Your Puppy to Go to Bed on Cue | Teacher's Pet With Victoria Stilwell

I think you're absolutely right! If people need cages for their dogs, they 
might as well leave them at the kennel where the picked them up. I don't 
think that's fair for a living being, like a dog, who is an active animal, 
to be kept in a cage for an entire day, like some people do with their 
dogs. If you can't even keep the dog in a kitchen, for example, you might 
as well rethink whether you can afford to have a dog.
comments.author: Diogo Pascoal

comments.author: Cutepikachu61

comments.text:
Sorry to bring up an old comment. I don't personally have a problem with 
your method but I think you just need to know that crate training isn't 
cruel when used appropriately. A puppy likes to have it's own private place 
which is its own territory. It's very useful for toilet training as a pup 
won't make a mess in it's own sleeping place and it helps it get used to 
travelling in crates. As long as it's never used as a punishment, it's a 
very rewarding technique.

comments.text:
Movies such as this help make Youtube good. Normally it takes up most of my 
business day. HOWEVER the vast majority of everyday people are slowly 
KILLING their pet dogs (without knowing it)!!! The stuff which they put 
into pet food induces cancerous cells and tends to make dogs pass away 
young. I figured that out the tough way when my doggie passed away aged 7. 
To save your animal's life make sure you look at Double Life Dog Diet (Use 
Google.)
comments.author: Manoj Kumar

comments.text:
That is sad and true, but its not really the idea of locking them up, its 
more like the idea of telling them go to sleep, go to bed. Keep your dog 
busy during the night or morning or whatever, put 2 stuffed kongs in their 
"bed/crate" with a toy the absolutely love and leave for the day, they'll 
be fine for at least 3-5 hours. I know its not great, but a destructive dog 
needs to be in a crate while your gone, until they learn not to be 
destructive.
comments.author: Tara Gharavi

comments.text:
I used to work for the humane society. We used to try to keep the dogs 
occupied as much as possible. Sitting there in these kennels they would 
loose hope! You could tell what dogs have been there for many months. They 
would sleep all the time, be depressed as if the life got sucked out of 
them.It's ABSOLUTELY HEARTbreaking!That's why I don't like CAGES!!I also 
use KONGS...I stuff them with all kinds of food and my dogs stay busy with 
them for a good while.They are my best friends and family!!!
comments.author: nogero7

comments.text:
I don't like cages!!! If you have a pup you have to leave home for some 
time...use those retractable fences. I used them in my kitchen area when my 
pups were little.It gave them open space, ceramic floors easy to clean up. 
Try looking yourself in a bathroom with no tv, radio, nothing but you and 
your shadow. No really just try if fro 10min. Now try to stay in there for 
6 to 8hrs. You would go INSANE! No living creature should ever be behind 
bars!! It's complete torture!!!
comments.author: nogero7

comments.text:
We use the bed command whenever we want our dog to chill put. We have beds

Oh my mistake didn't read most of what you have type my mistake. 2, I 
haven't seen a dog/puppy thats allergic to peanut butter. But if you don't 
want to risk that, use cheese, that you can cut in cubes. Those are good 
treats for dogs! I suggest you look info, if your not sure if your puppy 
can lick/eat peanut butter. Plus, you can ask your vet about his teeth and 
what he can and can not eat. So your puppy doesn't use much time on the 
Kong toy. You can put it's food in there or find snacks online
